Explanation:

There are many different shapes that can be drawn using SVG path elements. We can divide these shapes into simple shapes and compound shapes. 

A simple shape is a shape that can be drawn with only one path element and using only four basic commands: move to, line to, curve to, and close path. A circle can be drawn using only move to, line to, and close path commands. The path element for a circle would be:

<path d="M 49.47 26.27 L 55.28 65.93 L 48.51 77.47 Z" />

This shape uses a move to command (M) to move to the position of the center of the circle, then a line to command (L) to draw the circumference of the circle, and finally, a close path command (Z) to complete the circle.

When we examine the path element for the first shape, it doesn't fit within the above criteria. Instead of using three basic commands, this path element uses five commands with the M command used twice to define the start and end points of the triangle. This suggests that the shape is a compound shape made up of other simple shapes.

A compound shape is created by combining simpler shapes together to create a more complex shape. In this case, the heptagon shape is made up of a pentagon and a hexagon, and both of these shapes are made up of simple shapes. The compound shape is formed by drawing the pentagon and hexagon separately, then combining them together using the close path command (Z) to complete the shape.

The path element for the heptagon shape using five commands, including the line to command (L) used to connect the two pentagons, would be:

<path d="M 49.47 26.27 L 55.28 65.93 L 56.43 26.97 L 36.76 81.76 L 40.83 84.11 L 48.51 77.47 Z"/>

This shape contains a pentagon and a hexagon, each with a unique shape and position. By using the close path command (Z) to connect the shapes together, we create a closed shape that resembles a heptagon, as required.

Similarly, we can explain the other shapes using their path elements and describe the relationships between simple and compound shapes.
